awd_abstract_narration:
This mathematical research project deals with probabilistic properties (or stochasticity) in deterministic systems. Many deterministic systems exhibit random behavior due to sensitive dependence on initial conditions.  The goal of the present project is to develop methods of predicting the behavior of such systems using a statistical approach.  Particular attention will be paid to describing the dynamics on short spatial and long temporal scales.  The methods developed during this project will have applications to several fields, including probability theory, number theory, and statistical physics. The investigator also will continue his synergistic activities including organizing conferences, giving lectures and minicourses on recent advances in dynamics, writing survey papers, and mentoring graduate students.

The investigator will work on limit theorems for dynamical systems. The main directions of research will concern (1) local limit theorems and related asymptotic expansions and (2) limit theorems for toral translations and other zero entropy systems. The methods will be drawn from dynamical systems and probability theory.  In particular the investigations will rely on a spectral approach and renormalization techniques.  The connection between the two parts of the project is that the limit theorems for renormalization dynamics developed in the first part of this project will play important role in the second part.

por.por_cntn:
The project was devoted to developing new tools for descrbing random behavior of deterministic systems. For such system exact computations are usually impossible so one has to revert to statistical approach for perdicting their behavior, using the tools from probability theory. The project resulted in new sharp limit theorems for both hyperbolic systems which exhibit expoenntial instability of the nearby orbits and for regular systems where the analysis relied on the study of appropriate renormalization dynamics. In particular, the PI has proved local limit theorems for continuos time systems and also obtained a new class of limit theorems-temporal limit theorem for a wide class of systems. The tempral limit theorem provide a new way of statistical description of the system where a single orbit is fixed but the system is observed at random times. 

The limit theorems obtained during the projects is applied to obtain a sharp asymptotics of mixing rates for several classes of systems with both localized and extended phase space. The later case provides a natural framework for study the system of statistical mechanics and also for motion in random media. 

The project has been used for training of young researcher including three students and three postdoctoral fellows mentored at the univeristy of Maryland. In particular, two students defended their dissertation. The thesis of Kasun Fernando was devoted to interaction of probability and dynamics including refined limit theorems for dynamical systems using the spectral approach as well as finding new expansions in the classical Central Limit Theorem using the renrmalization dynamcs. The thesis of Jing Zhou was devoted to stochastic aspects of Fermi acceleration. In particualr, she described in her thesis new classes of robust exponential accelerators.
